column2: Last year, Ash Pereira called the police in her hometown of Enterprise, Alabama, to report a rape. The date of the alleged crime was nearly 15 years earlier; the accused, her now ex-husband, Jason Greathouse. Pereira, now 30, was locked in a bitter custody dispute with the man, a former youth pastor who impregnated her when she was 15 and he was 25. What ensued was shocking to Pereira and many observers: Her ex was allowed to plead to a misdemeanor, did not have to register as a sex offender, and maintains partial custody of their 14-year-old daughter. Inside the Rape Case Tearing a Rhode Island Town Apart Pereira, meanwhile, had to defend herself against accusations that she was an unfit mother and that she was using the statutory rape accusation as a cudgel to get Greathouse to give up his child. The battle has now pitted mother against daughter, with Pereira claiming her mother was the driving force behind her childhood marriage and her mother claiming Pereira is simply out for blood. â€œI really feel for my daughter, I really do,â€ Pereiraâ€™s mother, Jennie Jett, told The Daily Beast. â€œ[But] people donâ€™t understand everything that happened.â€ â€œYouâ€™ve given your body to someone and you need to take responsibility for your own actionsâ€ Growing up, Pereira was used to feeling like an outsider. A self-described â€œmilitary brat,â€ she bounced between four states before her 13th birthday: Louisiana, Tennessee, Alabama, New York, then back to Alabama, near the naval base in Enterprise. One of the only constants in her life was religion: No matter where she went, her parents always joined a church. Pereira and her brother spent three days a week in the pews, learning scripture andâ€”as Pereira puts itâ€”having â€œthe fear of hell absolutely burned into our heads.â€ At age 13, shortly after moving to Enterprise, Pereira developed a severe eating disorderâ€”a result, she says, of once again struggling to fit in with new classmates. Instead of getting her treatment, Pereira says, her mother pulled her out of school and attempted to cure the disorder herself. â€œMy mom thought Jesus could fix everything,â€ she said. (Her mother claims Pereira was â€œnot cooperativeâ€ when she tried to bring her to counseling sessions, as many anorexics are.) It was around that time that Pereiraâ€™s mother enrolled her in a youth group with Greathouse, a charming 24-year-old pastor from her favorite Christian supply store. Pereira had her issues with religionâ€”she once got in trouble for asking a teacher who said suicide was a sin whether she would go to hell for smokingâ€”but she says Greathouse was different from other church leaders. He was more progressive than her parents, and seemed to actually listen to her. He treated her, she said, â€œlike an adult.â€ Greathouse did not respond to multiple calls and emails seeking comment for this story, nor did his civil and criminal attorneys. A few months after they met, Greathouse moved in with Pereiraâ€™s family. He wanted to go to college but couldn't afford rent, she says, so her parents offered him their spare bedroom. Pereira was still being homeschooled, and with Greathouse in the house, she says, the two were together â€œconstantly.â€ Slowly, a flirtation developed. She says she was 14 the first time they had sex, after listening to a sermon in her parentsâ€™ living room. If Pereiraâ€™s parents noticed what was going on, she says, they didnâ€™t say anything. (Her brother says he tried to raise the issue with their mother once, but she threatened to ground him if he brought it up again.) When Pereira finally told her mother what had happened, she says, â€œshe turned around and kind of made it my responsibility.â€ â€œShe was like, â€˜Well, youâ€™re supposed to save this for marriage, and [now] youâ€™ve given your body to someone and you need to take responsibility for your own actions,â€™â€ she recalled. Her mother recalls the situation differently. She claims Pereira lied about her age to Greathouse and only sought out her mother to confess her deception after the fact. She says she never blamed her daughter and held Greathouse â€œaccountable,â€ though she did not specify how. â€œI remember when I told him [her age], he just about fell apart and was shaking,â€ she said. â€œI believe 100 percent that he did not know.â€ But thereâ€™s no denying that by 15, Pereira was pregnant with Greathouseâ€™s baby. (Greathouse has admitted as much in court filings.) She says she was panicked, and her father was furious, but her mother seemed unconcerned. â€œShe seemed more excited about being a grandmother than she was upset about what had happened to her daughter,â€ her brother recalled. Eventually, she says, the family decided the best course of action was for the two to be wed. â€œI felt like I owed it to him and my mom and God to make things work,â€ Pereira recalled. â€œI was coerced into understanding that I was supposed to be with this person for the rest of my life because we had sex.â€ (Her mother claims the wedding was Pereiraâ€™s idea.) On May 4, 2007, five days after her 16th birthday, Pereira marched to the courthouse and married her 25-year-old pastor. â€œHe knew how old I was for so longâ€ A few months into her marriage with Greathouse, Pereira started to have doubts. She had just started work as a hostess at her local Ruby Tuesdayâ€™s, and her coworkers were openly horrified by her situation. She told a friend, Katelynd Anderson, that she hated sleeping in the same bed with her husband. On top of that, Pereira claims, Greathouse had started acting strangely, staying out at night on â€œrunsâ€ with a female coworker and evading her questions. (Greathouse alleges in court documents that it was Pereira who cheated on him.) So one day, Pereira picked up her paycheck and didnâ€™t go home. She spent a couple weeks couch-surfing until Andersonâ€™s family offered to take her in for good. She got a new jobâ€”ironically, she says Ruby Tuesdayâ€™s fired her for being underageâ€”and used her next paycheck to hire a lawyer. The divorce process was expensive, and she was an underemployed teenager, so when Greathouse put up a fight, she says, she didnâ€™t have the resources to fight back. She settled for 50/50 custody and no child support. At the time, Pereira says, she thought she couldnâ€™t press charges against Greathouse because they had been married. Instead, she tried to move on with her life. She finished her GED and enrolled in college; moved with a partner to Tennessee; broke up with him; pursued a career in acting; started her own pedicab business. Often she found herself between jobs and struggling to make ends meet; occasionally she suffered physical symptoms of PTSD so severe she wound up in the emergency room. She says she tried to think of Greathouse as little as possible, going so far as to change his name on her phone so she could pretend it was someone else when he called. Then, early last year, Greathouse tried to introduce a court order in Tennessee that would give him primary custody of their child. (The two disagree on whether Pereira had knowingly signed off on this before.) The dispute was intense: In court documents, Greathouse accused Pereira of being an absent parent, of prioritizing her career over her child, and of introducing their daughter to the occult. He also included an 8-year-old affidavit from Pereiraâ€™s second husband, claiming that she cheated on him and falsely accused him of abusing her. (In an email to Pereira last year, the second husband wrote that anything he said at the time was â€œthe bias of a jaded ex-husbandâ€ and â€œshould not even be admissible at this point.â€) Most infuriating to Pereira, Greathouse repeated to the court her motherâ€™s claim that she lied about her ageâ€”something she and her father say would have been impossible. â€œI was in his junior high youth group. He taught me how to drive,â€ she scoffed. â€œHe knew how old I was for so long.â€ It was traumatizing, Pereira says, to watch Greathouse take the stand and deny that he had been in the wrong. More than anything, though, it confused her that a judge would consider granting him custody in the first place. â€œI tried to tell them what happened to me, and they just would not recognize it,â€ she said. â€œThey would not take it seriously because he had never been fully convicted.â€ A â€˜sickeningâ€™ national situation Pereiraâ€™s account may be shocking, but it isnâ€™t unique. In the overwhelming majority of U.S. states, child marriage is still perfectly legal, as long as a parent or judge consents. According to one study, nearly 300,000 minors were married in the U.S. between 2000 and 2018â€”most of them underage girls married to men at least four years older. Once theyâ€™re in these marriages, says Freidy Reiss, founder of anti-child-marriage charity Unchained At Last, the girls are stuck in a â€œnightmarish legal trap.â€ What would have been considered a crimeâ€”sex between a minor girl and an adult manâ€”is now perfectly legal. And their options for leaving are drastically limited. In most states, Reiss explained, minors who leave home are considered runaways, meaning police can return them to their homes and even arrest them if they donâ€™t comply. Most domestic violence shelters wonâ€™t accept victims under the age of 18 for similar reasons. Young people also have a hard time securing lawyers, because contracts with minors are usually considered voidable, and they cannot bring a legal proceeding like a divorce or restraining order in their own name. Because of this, Reiss said, sheâ€™s seen numerous child brides turn to suicide. â€œWe honestly have set up a system where I can understand why someone would think, â€˜The only way out for me is death,â€™â€ she said. Laws protecting women of all ages who are impregnated by their rapists are not much better. More than a third of states still require a felony conviction in order to terminate the rapistâ€™s right to custody of the childâ€”more than whatâ€™s required in cases of child abuse, neglect, molestation, or a myriad of other reasons a judge might terminate parental rights. And thatâ€™s a problem because, while an estimated 17,000 to 32,000 rape-related pregnancies occur each year, less than 1 percent of rapes result in a felony conviction. As a result, stories abound of women who are forced to share custody with their alleged attackers: The Nebraska woman whose assailant won visitation rights despite pleading guilty to third-degree sexual assault; the Pennsylvania woman whose rapist maintained a right to shared custody even from jail; the woman in Detroit who was forced to split custody with the man who abducted and raped her at age 13. (The judge in the latter case eventually reversed his ruling.) Perhaps most similar to Pereira is the case of Jessica Stallings, another Alabama native who says her motherâ€™s half-brother started having sex with her when she was 13 and he was 20. Stallings says her parents did nothing to stop the abuse and instead forced her to marry her assailant, who eventually impregnated her multiple times. When Stallings finally mustered the courage to leave, the court granted him visitation rights. Stallings was still fighting for full custody in 2019, when Alabama passed a law requiring courts to terminate the parental rights of convicted rapists. But the law required Stallings to get a felony conviction against her uncle, which she was not able to doâ€”despite twice going to a grand jury with birth certificates, medical records and DNA evidence. â€œItâ€™s sickening,â€ Stallings told The Washington Post. â€œIâ€™ve spent my entire life scared to death of my rapist, and now, Iâ€™m fighting him for custody of my children.â€ â€œI donâ€™t want to have to ask my rapistâ€™s permission for thingsâ€ Greathouse and his attorneys have repeatedly argued that Pereira only reported him to get the upper hand in their custody dispute; to â€œuse the circumstances of the childâ€™s conception as a way to force a change in custody,â€ as one court filing put it. But Pereira is adamant that her reasoning was more complicated. To start with, she says, she didnâ€™t even know she could press charges until after the latest custody battle started. And even then, she says, the point of reporting him wasnâ€™t to win a legal fight, but to earn her freedom. â€œPeople donâ€™t understand that [even though] the situation was so many years ago, I still have to cope with it to this day, and I still have to co-parent with someone who took my virginity as a grown man,â€ she said. â€œI donâ€™t want to have to ask my rapistâ€™s permission for things,â€ she added. â€œNo one should ever have to do that.â€ Greathouse was arrested on Aug. 12, 2020, on a charge of second-degree rape, and released on bond that same day, according to court records. But Pereira says she didnâ€™t hear anything from the district attorneyâ€™s office for weeks, and didnâ€™t speak to an attorney on the case until the day of Greathouseâ€™s sentencing. She was on her way from Nashville to Enterprise for the first day of trial when a victimsâ€™ services officer called to tell her it was off, and that Greathouse was taking a plea deal. He copped to contributing to the delinquency of a minorâ€”a misdemeanorâ€”and got a two-year suspended sentence, meaning he will likely never spend a day in jail. Coffee County District Attorney Tom Anderson, whose office handled the case, said in an email that he had taken more than 80 cases to verdict and would have been â€œshockedâ€ if a jury returned anything other than a not guilty ruling in this one. He said the defense could argue that Pereira only filed the complaint in order to win the custody battle, potentially swaying the jury against her. And in an interview with AL.com, defense attorney David Harrison did just that, claiming he had text messages in which Pereira threatened to have Greathouse charged if he didnâ€™t give her full custody. â€œThis person used the court system here to try to, in my opinion, coerce mentally, emotionally, somebody to give up custody of his child,â€ Harrison said. Pereira denies sending Greathouse any direct threats and says she could have explained her texts to the DAâ€™s office if theyâ€™d ever asked her. But she also doesnâ€™t understand why any of this matters. She is 30, Greathouse is 40, and their daughter turned 14 in August. If the jury could do basic arithmetic, that should be all the evidence theyâ€™d need. â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter if I became the worst person imaginable after the fact,â€ she said. â€œHe still did the crime. He still was a 25-year-old man who got a 15-year-old pregnant. And thereâ€™s nothing stopping him from doing whatever he wants in the future.â€ Jenny Carrol, a professor at the University of Alabama Law School and former public defender, says she wasnâ€™t surprised by the prosecutorâ€™s decision to offer a plea deal. A jury might discount someone who didnâ€™t appear to be the â€œperfect victim,â€ she said, and an under-resourced prosecutorâ€™s office might see a decade-old case as low priority. But just because the case is typical, she added, doesnâ€™t make it right. â€œIf anything, it just highlights how broken the system is when it comes to sexual assault,â€ she said. The family court judge has yet to make a decision in Greathouse and Pereiraâ€™s custody dispute, but Tennessee is one of the states that requires a felony conviction to terminate parental rights. For the time being, the two continue to share custody of their daughter. Pereira insisted on attending Greathouseâ€™s sentencing hearing, and wrote her victimâ€™s statement from her fatherâ€™s wrap-around porch the night before. In the courtroom that day, she told the story of a childhood cut short, of adults who failed to protect her, and of a life spent dealing with the impact. And she told the judge how terrified she is that Greathouse would do something like this again. â€œFifteen years ago, I was forced to grow up prematurely,â€ she wrote. â€œIâ€™ve spent the past 15 years trying to co-parent with my rapist to provide a better life for our child. Fifteen years was too much. And now, due to the courtâ€™s desire to settle cases quickly rather than seek justice for those wronged, Iâ€™m forced to continue seeing my rapist weekly. Iâ€™m forced to relive my trauma every week.â€ Worst of all, she added, she had never received an apology. â€œ[Greathouse] doesnâ€™t think he is wrong or guilty of his actions,â€ she wrote, â€œand to me that is the most dangerous kind of criminal.â€ Read more at The Daily Beast. column2: By Hyonhee Shin SEOUL (Reuters) - A South Korean has crossed the heavily fortified border in a rare defection to North Korea, South Korea's military said on Sunday. The Joint Chiefs of Staff (JCS) said it carried out a search operation after detecting the person around 9:20 p.m. (1220 GMT) on Saturday on the eastern side of the Demilitarised Zone (DMZ) separating the two Koreas. "We've confirmed that the person crossed the Military Demarcation Line border about 10:40 p.m. (1340 GMT) and defected to the North," the JCS said. The JCS said it could not confirm whether the person was alive, but sent a notice to the North via a military hotline asking for protection. The border crossing, which is illegal in South Korea, came as North Korea carries out strict anti-coronavirus measures since shutting borders in early 2020, though it has not confirmed any infections. A public and political uproar emerged after North Korean troops shot dead a South Korean fisheries official who went missing at sea in September 2020, for which Pyongyang blamed anti-virus rules and apologised. Two months earlier, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un declared a national emergency and sealed off a border town after a North Korean defector who he said had COVID-19 symptoms illegally crossed the border into the North from the South. The North's prolonged lockdowns and restrictions on inter-provincial movement have also pushed the number of North Korean defectors arriving in the South to an all-time low. Cross-border relations soured after denuclearisation negotiations between Pyongyang and Washington stalled since a failed summit in 2019. South Korea and a U.S.-led U.N. force are technically still at war with North Korea since the 1950-1953 Korean War ended in an armistice rather than a peace treaty.
